moves.1. d4: I won't anotate the whole game, very classical queen gambit play
moves.1... d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. g3 Bb4+ 5: White has a slight advance but a weak king and all his pieces are on white squares, vulnerable to a LSB attack. White controls the open file but the black pieces on the queen side are dangerous.
moves.26. Rd3d1: Rook of the bishop fireline and preventing a further Qa1
moves.26... bxc4: good move If white takes : 27. bxc4 ; 27... Rb2 and white is in serious trouble
moves.27. Ra7: So that white decides not to take
moves.27... Bb7: menacing to take the f3 pawn.
moves.28. Kf2: to protect f3 but the white royal pair is subject to a further Rb2 and the white queen will be lost.
moves.28... Bd5: puting pressure on b3 and f3
moves.29. Rxa5: A free pawn is not somthing to neglect
moves.29... cxb3: Now white is in serious trouble
moves.30... Rxb3:
Black has several menaces : Rxf3+  Bxf3 and Rb2 are equally dangerous.
But this move is a mistake. White has only one move but it's the beginning of a winning sequence and I was very happy to have found it 2 moves before.
moves.31. Rxd5:
!
This annihilates the attack on f3 and if 31... Rb2 ; 32. Rd2 does the job.
moves.31... exd5: Black takes and has now material advantage but not for long.
moves.32. Ra8+: ! Black has only one move available
moves.32... Kh7: only move - the black rook hangs
moves.33... g6: 33... Qg6 was another option, not better.
moves.34. Qxb3:
Now white has a material advantage.
Black's only hope is to promote one of the passed pawns but white's winning sequence is not finished.
moves.35. Qb8: Mating menace. Black has only one move.
moves.35... Qd4+: Clever, for it forces the white king to go away from  the center where it could block the passed pawns.
moves.36. Kg2: king in safety. Not that black cannot hope for permetual chess because the white king can go to h3
moves.36... Qg7: only move to avoid the mate
moves.37... Qb2+: to fire the white king further away
